context: A boy and his dog, lost.  Sounds like the title of a good book.
What a cute little guy!  So glad they found him and his dog.
So happy he is safe.
Thank the Lord! So glad the dog stayed by his side to keep him safe and warm!
So glad he is safe and sound. I have to say though, it took them almost 10 hours to find him. A trained dog would have found him much faster, he was only a mile away.
Grateful the little guy and his dog were found.  Wonder how the parents lost him...what were they doing?  A lot of love from the community of 600 volunteers to help the parents, parent.

replies.context: Kids should be able to walk a short distance in safe areas. They can also move fast when playing and get lost. At six, there are lots of investigations and explorations some of them do to understand the world around them.  A GPS locator is a good idea for some.

Thanks, do agree the GPS locator is a worthwhile tool.  Safe areas to me is questionable.  One never knows what dangers exists, thus the reason for my comment.  Believe a parent is responsible for bringing a child into the world and responsible for their lifetime support and care.  Too many people have children that are not committed or fitted to parents themselves.

I agree.  However, kids should be encouraged to explore their surroundings and learn about their world.  Many people live in “safe” communities where neighbors look out for each other.  I do. It is always sad to see neighborhoods where parents must fear to be more than a few feet from their children, or keep them in locked houses all day because of safety.  That doesn’t mean parents should be unaware of their children’s location. 

Kids need to be able to “run and play” to build strength and mental agility.  This kid just got lost.  A GPS locator is called for on most kids like that. Loyal dogs are often a good idea.  We had one that stopped unauthorized adults from coming near the children. The kids loved him. Thank goodness for his dog.

Agree...children and animals require space to explore and learn.  Nature truly is magnificent!  In fact, God given.  

Even like the GPS locator.  Great idea!  

No animal, child or adult should ever have to fear and be locked in.  However, reality is, parenting is more than giving birth and letting them run wild and not pay attention to their whereabouts.  Granted, we can all get lost (no matter the age).  Therefore, even more important that the parenting skills be in place to be able to assist in an emergency.  Forget the outside concern of mankind, but include mother nature issues such as holes, sprains, tangled in brush etc.  Children require supervision.  Supervision is the parents responsibility.  

Now, add the financial resources expended by the community.  Yes, 600 volunteers working together...beautiful community and unity.  However, not always the case.  First responders who may have aided elderly folks but were spending their time walking around looking for this child.  An elderly family member that may need assistance, but everyone took off to look for the kid that the parents lost sight of during the day...I question several decisions on behalf of the parents parental skills.

When the child does grow up and relocates or travels, that support system may not exist for him outside the community.  Will he be equipped with the necessary skills or will he think back and believe...  oh, someone will take care of me.

That is why we need to learn as much about the world around us as we can.  We also need to teach our children how to plan activities and defend themselves. Bumps and a few bruises are normal and helpful to learning.
Agree

Aside from that, moving all their expensive school books to a tablet which could also have GPS would not only also get the children less to carry around but by allowing some games on the devices (locked out during school and parent defined hours) would also give them a reason to keep the device with them. 

So a phone itself is only one item that could be used to assist.

replies.context: For crying out loud, the world has turned so negative that enjoying a heart warming story is not allowed?

Go to Disneyland if you have to have a happy ending. Several years ago in the mountains of Utah, a family with an autistic 10 year old boy were camping. On the way back to camp from the lake he took off a different direction. There were about 500 responders looking for him for 4 days. He was finally coaxed-out of the trees 3 miles from camp. He had been hiding the whole time even when responders were just feet from his location. The police and his family failed to mentioned his condition and that he would hide on purpose. It was nice that he was found but it sure left a sour taste in all our mouths.

I know the world is far from perfect and I certainly don't know the whole story but i I am sorry for what your search team went through.  However, what part of this little boy's missing was his fault?

I understand. I'm not blaming the child and I'm not blaming THIS child. I'm saying the family needs to release this kind of information to the search responders. This search seems similar to the Utah one. It might make it easier and faster to locate the child.

context: Al Gore invented Happy Endings...

And on the 9th day God looked down on his wide eyed children and decided, they need a companion.

So God made a Dog.

God said I need an animal who no matter what you didn’t do or couldn’t take or didn’t win or couldn’t make, will love you without judgment just the same. I need an animal strong enough to pull sleds and find bombs and yet gentle enough to love babies, find the lost, lead the blind and help a soldier forget the horror of war. An animal that will spend all day on a couch with a resting head and supportive eyes for the broken heart.

So God made a Dog.

It had to be an animal who would remain patient and loyal even through loneliness. An animal who would bring the family together with an open heart. An animal to bark, and then pant and then reply with the rapid wag of a tail, when their best friend says, “let’s go for a ride in the car.”

So God made a Dog.

God said I need an animal who would stand at your side when the world around you collapses. An animal to lie next to you during the long nights of pain and sorrow when it hurts to move, to talk, or think, or even be. An animal to give you strength when you have none of your own. An animal to fight when you have no fight left, to hold onto your soul to keep you in this world. An animal to be your companion and guide in this world and the next. An animal to wait for you on the other side or stand guard in your absence until they can join you for eternity.

So God made a Dog.

replies.context: I remember a man saying something just like this almost but I can't remember his name! I am 61 yrs old and I have always had a dog ever since I could remember, sometimes we had 2 dogs like I do now. I have cats to and love them  but I really love my dogs!

Absolutely Beautiful. I have always trusted my dogs instincts over a human being. There is only one exception; my late Husband.

God Bless ...
